cautions: Attachments The attachments are a vital part of the book. it contain a lot of information for the clarity and the success of the treatments Basic rules and contraindications for acupuncture In the following instances one should exercise caution before deciding to use acupuncture and be meticulous in choosing acupuncture points. In cases of exhaustion and fatigue it is preferable to support the patient with moxa on St36 and/or Cv6 If the patient has been fasting there is risk of fainting. It is preferable to eat 30 minutes before receiving acupuncture after a prolonged fast. Do not needle after a heavy meal or if the patient feels stuffed. Exercise caution in needling when the patient is experiencing an extreme emotional state, e.g. joy or sadness. Needling in these circumstances may result in reverse flow of CHI. Immediately after conception, acupuncture should only be done by a doctor who understands the process of pregnancy from conception through birth and the unique changes in the patterns of CHI flow which take place during this process. 6. Do not needle in instances where there is dissonance between the complexion and the pulse in terms of pattern diagnostics. This shows an energetic imbalance. Breathing techniques should be used to regain balance before using acupuncture. When the weather does not support the treatment, e.g. in extremely stormy weather avoid strong needle stimulation especially when treating acute pathologies. In extreme heat, do not use moxa. When the time of the treatment does not support the treatment, e.g. during the evening and night time avoid strong needle stimulation unless the pathology is strong and acute. PREGNANCY The process of pregnancy is one of upmost importance. The physician must fully understand and support this physiologic process in a very precise manner. The body of a pregnant woman is constantly working to nourish the fetus and sustain the pregnancy. We must have these objectives in mind when treating a pregnant woman. One of the most important things to remember is the energetic balance in her body is markedly different from a state of non-pregnancy. Consequently, there are acupuncture points which would be dangerous to manipulate or cause to return to their prior state of function (as they were before pregnancy).  The reasons for this include the points’ function, the direction in which they send energy, their meeting/influence on other points and the points’ location on the body. Examples CO4 is contraindicated throughout pregnancy. This is due to its strong yang quality which can cause contractions. For this same reason, it is also a very effective point during labor. SP6 is contraindicated for the entire pregnancy because it is responsible for balancing the subtle environmental changes in the womb e.g. dampness and heat. Needling may disrupt this delicate balance. Ren6 is contraindicated because of its location BL23 and DU4 are both contraindicated because of their locations. Also, DU4 has a strong energetic effect on the kidneys and BL23 has a strong connection with the DAI MAI, both systems should be used cautiously during pregnancy. Additional Cautions A pregnant woman who is very weak should not be needled. Exercise extreme caution in treatment if the patient has a history of miscarriages Do not needle a pregnant woman experiencing extreme emotional tension resulting in extreme anger, sadness or anxiety. Do not needle a pregnant woman suffering extreme acute pain in the upper or lower abdomen. Points Forbidden During Pregnancy The beginning of pregnancy is determined according to the time of ovulation and not according to the time of the last menses Points Forbidden with Moxa There are a couple of acupuncture points that per the classics, are contraindicated with moxa. The main reason for this is their proximity to vital blood vessels. The heat from moxa on these points can cause changes to the bodies of these vessels as well as to the flow of blood inside of them. REN-15, SP-9, ST-38, GB-1, ST-9, LU-8 DU-15, DU-16, BL-10, GB-15, TH-23, BL-1, CO-20, Per the Nan Jing the use of the following points is forbidden with moxa. LU- 1,2,3,4,5,8 CO- 4,5,13 ST- 5,7,9,30,42 SP- 11, 12 HT- 1,3 SI- 16 BL- 40 KID- 3,10 PC-8 TH- 22 GB- 2,3 LIV- 2,3,10,11 Body Cun measurements 15 cun medial malleolus – knee joint 16 cun lateral malleolus – knee joint 14 cun posterior knee – gluteal crease 20 cun patella– superior border of symphysis pubis 19 cun knee joint – tuberosity of greater trochanter 2 cun superior border of patella – inferior border of patella 12 cun wrist joint – elbow joint 9 cun elbow joint – superior border of axilla 5 cun superior border of symphysis pubis – umbilicus 8 cun umbilicus – CV16 4 cun CV – line of ASIS 8 cun CV – mid axillary line 8 cun CV – acromion 3 cun GV – medial scapula 4.5 cun mid line – ST8 1.5 cun mid line – BL4 (half way between the inner cantus of the eye and the pupil) 3 cun midline – GB13 14 cun glabella – GV16 15 cun glabella – posterior hairline 3 cun glabella – anterior hairline 8 cun glabella – GV20 6 cun GV20 – GV16 5 Elements Chinese medicine divides the world of phenomenon into 5 elements, or per some translations “5 phases”. Each element has its own unique characteristics be they physical or metaphysical. The elements have a flow and rhythm unique to each one through which they are manifested in the world. Nonphysical associations of the organs include; direction and climate which are ideas associated with heaven.  When speaking of the elements, physical concepts include; taste, the organs themselves, tissue and bodily functions. The elements do not exist as individual entities. They are mutually involved in a closed-circuit relationship where one’s activity influences and is influenced by the activity (or lack thereof) of another. One of the most crucial relationships to be aware of amongst the elements is that of generating and controlling. Understand how the elements interact with each other, gives us a more complete understanding of the person in our care, the signs with which he is presenting and what elements are out of balance. While we consider all the elements when making a diagnosis, it is important to focus on the ones that are dominant and perhaps overcontrolling others. Over control can happen when an element is in a state of excess. Thus, it will seek to control an element that is weak. This will lead to further weakening of the controlled element. The same system of control and generating that exists on the micro level (in living organisms), exists on the macro level (in the universe at large). Their relationship’s and resulting effects can be observed in the climate, seasons, hourly etc. This perspective lays the groundwork for diagnosis and treatment in Chinese Medicine. Also, the food, sounds and emotions that are related to each element give us a deeper understanding of pathology as well as tools for treatment. Transport/Antique points There are 60 acupuncture points that are considered crucial energetic points on the body. These points allow us to balance the meridians in a unique manner per the energy that is needed. On the arm meridians, these points are located between the elbows and fingers. On the leg meridians, they are between the knees and toes. Each of the 12 primary meridians has points labeled; Jing-well, Ying-spring, Shu-stream, Jig-river and He-sea. These points have a direct connection to the 5 phases and the nourishing (sheng) cycle that is constantly at play. On the yin meridians, the first of these points is always associated with the wood element. On the yang meridians, the first will always be a metal point. With an understanding of 5 element theory, one can use these points in a variety of ways to balance and influence the 5 elements in the body. Mother point – This is the point associated with the element that nourishes/births the element of the relevant meridian i.e. LU9 & CO11 are both earth points on metal meridians. These will influence the process of earth nourishing metal. Child point – This is the point associated with the element that is nourished by the relevant meridian. They are also called “dispersal” points because their energetic flow is in the opposite direction of the nourishing cycle i.e. LU5 & CO2 are both water points on metal meridians and thus nourish the metal element with water energy. One should exercise caution when using these points as they cause energy to flow in the opposite direction than its normal coursing. Horary points – Theses are points associated with the element that the relevant meridian belongs to. LU8 and CO1 are metal points on metal meridians. These are generally used for two purposes; to strengthen the characteristic of an element and its influence on the body. Or, during treatments done at the time that the organ/meridian is dominant to increase that systems functionality even more. An example being using LU8 between 3-5 AM to increase the lungs’ metal energy. 5 ELEMENT POINTS 8 EXTRAORDINARY MERIDIANS The 8 extraordinary meridians are opened by using both a “master” and “couple” point. To allow for a good treatment one must follow a few basic rules Needle the master point first and the couple point second. Master points are needled on the left side on men and on the right for women. Couple points are needled on the right side for men and the left for women. When taking needles out, the couple point is removed first and the master point second. During a treatment where and extraordinary meridian is opened, the use of other points on that meridian is contraindicated (see intro to extraordinary points). The duration of needle retention is calculated per the time of day and what organ is dominant at the time of treatment. The practitioner should wait to feel 3 peaks in the pulse of the dominant organ, upon feeling the 3rd, needles are removed e.g. at noon one should wait to feel 3 peaks in the heart pulse. After the 3rd peak is felt, remove the needles in the correct order. Xi – cleft points There is a total of 16 Xi-cleft points on the body. 12 of them belong to the primary meridians and 4 to the 8 extraordinary meridians. “Xi” is used to describe a pool where energy from the meridian accumulates. These points can be used in the following situations. When we want to immediately increase and intensify the flow of energy in a meridian by tapping into the meridians internal reserves and not a deeper place of storage. Acute instances requiring immediate change in energy. Adjusting the direction of flow in the meridian. Xi – cleft points can also be used as reflex points. Palpation of these points can provide us with information regarding the meridians state of excess or deficiency. In deficiency, the point will feel sunken, soft, cold and lacking tension. In a state of excess, they will feel hard, protruding, hot, painful, tense and give exaggerated resistance. Mu Points There are 12 Mu points found on the body, one for each organ. These points have a yin nature and therefore influence the physical aspect of their associated organs. Another sign of these being yin in nature is their location. All of them are found on the anterior aspect of the body (chest, upper and lower abdomen). They are crucial points to influence the body’s function. The Mu points are used to influence the building of yin material of their associated organ. They are not used to influence the energetic aspect of organs. Doing so, is a task reserved for the Shu points. Additionally, Mu points are reflex points of their organs. Mu points Shu Points of the Bladder Meridian BL11 – HUI meeting of the bones. Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower border of spinous process T1 BL13 – SHU meeting point of the lungs Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T3 BL14 – SHU point of the pericardium Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T4 BL15 – SHU point of the heart Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T5 BL16 – SHU point of the DU Mai Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T6 BL17 – HUI meeting point of the blood and SHU point of the diaphragm Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T7 BL18 – SHU point of the liver Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T9 BL19 – SHU point of the gall bladder Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T10 BL20 – SHU point of the spleen Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T11 BL21 – Shu point of the stomach Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process T12 BL22 – Shu point of the triple burner Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process L1 BL23 – SHU point of the kidneys Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process L2 BL24 – SHU point of the sea of CHI Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process L3 BL25 – SHU point of the large intestine Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process L4 BL26 – SHU point of the gate of vitality Located 1.5 cun lateral to the lower boarder of spinous process L5 BL27 – SHU point of the small intestine Located 1.5 cun lateral to the first sacral foramen BL28 – SHU point of the urinary bladder Located 1.5 cun lateral to the second sacral foramen BL29 – SHU point of the sacrum Located 1.5 cun lateral to the third sacral foramen BL30 – SHU point of the anus Located 1.5 cun lateral to the fourth sacral foramen Ba Hui Meeting Points There are 8 meeting points on the body. Per the Ling Shu and Nei Ching, these points are used to treat warm disease. Additionally, they can be used to treat the system which they represent. Influential/8 meeting points (BA HUI) TMM Meeting points These points are important in understanding the physiology of the Tendo Muscular Meridians. The TMM, via these points, can stop a pathogen which has made its way into the body from further penetrating. We can tonify the defensive CHI at these areas using the TMM meeting points. DIVERGENT MEETING and EXIT POINTS The divergent meridians serve as a highway taking CHI from the yin meridians to the head. Since the yin meridians do not reach the head and brain, they divert from their main pathways and meet divergent pathways of the yang meridians. It is through these passages that yin CHI arrives at the head and brain. It is important to remember the pathways of the divergents so that we can follow the progression of CHI flow between the left and right side of the body. Shokanten Points Shokanten points are meeting points of the 6 warps. The above chart shows the 6 warps and their Shokanten points. These points are used when the practitioner wishes to do the following: Supporting one of the 6 warps Influencing the expression of an internal climate associated with one of the 6 warps e.g. cold water is influenced by Kid12. It will support the Tai Yang which expresses a climate of cold. Balancing the 9 continents When using Shokanten points one should consider all the above principals particularly the first 2. GROUP LUO POINTS These points can be used to draw upon the CHI of the meridians meeting there, for local or broader systemic energetic influences. Important Reminder: TH8 is a forbidden point in acupuncture. It can be manipulated by way of massage or moxa. The Clock The use of opposites on the Chinese clock is known as “mid-day -mid night”. This is a fundamental law giving us insight to the energetic changes which occur throughout the day.  This principle is rooted in seeing the dynamic balance in cycles of energy. The 24-hour day is divided in to 12 hours of yang dominance (12:00-00:00) and 12 hours of yin dominance (00:00-12:00). Bearing in mind the principle of polarity of yin and yang, the Chinese clock shows us that when an organ is at its energetic peak, another organ (its clock opposite) is experiencing an energetic ebb e.g. at 12:00 pm the heart is at its peak. At the same time gall bladder is experiencing its ebb. This reciprocal waxing and waning of yin and yang is constantly taking place. Clinically this is a very important principle to consider, in that if we tonify an organ we also suppress its clock opposite. During a treatment, one must consider the system being needled and the system that is dominant at the time of the treatment as well as the opposites of each. The reason for this is that if we support an organ in treatment, we can potentially weaken (by suppressing) its clock opposite. THE CHINESE CLOCK MIDDAY MIDNIGHT LAW PULSE In Chinese Medicine the skill of pulse diagnosis is one that the practitioner will hone for the rest of his life. It is the most trustworthy diagnostic tool for the experienced practitioner. At the most basic level of pulse diagnoses, one can differentiate and understand the states of the 3 Jiao and the Zang and Fu organs. As one acquires more skill, the pulses of the 8 extraordinary meridians will begin to be felt more clearly. When the 8 extraordinary are more clear, the practitioner will be able to diagnose disruption in the function of each organ in the body per the 3 all-encompassing aspects of life:  spirit, physical function of each organ and the amount and potential of prenatal Jing available. The pulses introduced here lay the groundwork for the basic initial pulse diagnoses used by practitioners of Classical Chinese Medicine. Classical Pulses Pulses of the 8 Extradoridanry Meridians Nei Ching Pulses Ba Gua The Ba Gua form the underlying philosophy of the book of changes (the I Ching). The central concept of the Ba Gua express’s the interactions   between the energies of heaven and earth and all that exists between them. Every interaction of the Ba Gua results in the actualization of a new phenomenon. This new phenomenon is a direct result of the specific qualities and dynamic relationship of the Ba Gua that brought it into being. The Ba Gua are geometric structures made up of 8 trigrams. Each trigram describes an interaction between yang (represented by a full line) and yin (represented by a broken line). The relationships between the trigrams listed below help us gain perspective on process of creation and the dynamic balancing that is constantly occurring in the universe. The use of what I call I-Ching acupuncture, requires impeccable skill which is acquired through understanding the trigrams, 5 elements, 5 phases, the 4 seasons, the dynamic relationships between organs and meridians, understanding what is felt in the pulse, and the ability to synchronize these things. There is no doubt that without the I – Ching, Chinese Medicine would not have developed to the state that it is in today. I firmly believe that without the understanding of the trigrams, ones understanding of Chinese Medicine will be incomplete. Deep Energy Each organ in the body has a deep energy which activates and preserves the dynamic balance of that organ and thus does so for the entire body. For example, the expanding and contracting of the lungs and large intestine require the motion of the wood element. Without this wood energy, the physiological process of breathing and peristalsis would not be possible. Therefore, when using a meridian one must consider it’s deep energy which influences the body as a unit. If a person is experiencing mental and energetic stagnation, we would not use points on the stomach meridian. Doing so may intensify the innate heaviness of the earth element. On the other hand, using the spleen meridian, may intensify the fire elements energy which can be beneficial in this instance. cautions: Da Chang Large Intestine / COLON Da Chang 大腸 Stimulation and guidance for direction, direction and definition Bride and transfer The colon is responsible for the transformation of all the murk. All waste products pass through this site and from there the form changes. 5 elements phase: Metal Celestial stem: Geng 庚 Terrestrial Branch: Mao 卯 Trigram: Zhen 震 Six Division: Yang Ming Climate: Dryness Deep Energy: Wood Direction: West Season: Autumn Chinese Clock: 05:00-07:00 Animal: Rabbit Co 1 SHANG YANG Merchant of Yang 商陽 Shang - merchant, 5th note on Chinese musical scale Yang - yang energy Shang is the sound related to the metal element. LU-11 and CO-1 are the only points on the metal meridians that have a connection to Shang. From here we learn that these point are effective in treating problems of the throat, the place where the 5 tones are formed. These points influence the vocal chords and the sounds that they make. CO-1 treats higher tones and LU-11 treats lower ones. Likewise as this point is the metal point of the Colon it has the ability to concentrate yang CHI at its peak Co 2 ER JIAN Second Space 二間 Er - 2 or second Jian - portion, space, hole Er Jian is the second point on the meridian. It is also the distal point to the metacarpal phalangeal joint. The points name is a reminder of its location Co 3 SAN JIAN Third Space 三間 San - 3, 3rd Jian - hole, space, part San Jian is the 3rd point on the meridian Contraindicated in pregnancy Frequent dispersal of this point can lead to deafness and knee pain Co 5 YANG XI Valley of Yang 陽谿 Yang – yang, that which completes yin Xi - stream, valley Yang Xi is located on the yang aspect of the hand between 2 tendons that function as the walls of the valley. Co 14 BI NAO Upper Arm 臂臑 Bi - arm Nao - upper A reference to the point’s location Co 15 JIAN YU shoulder bone 肩髃 Jian - shoulder Yu - corner, clavicula The point’s name describes its location at the meeting of the humerus and acromion Exercise caution with patients with heart conditions because this point can cause too much yang CHI to penetrate the heart. Co 16 JU GU Large Bone 巨骨 Ju - big, long, large Gu - bone Ju Gu is the ancient name for the Clavicle This points name describes the bulge at the clavicle scapula joint Do not needle on patients with eye problems Co 19 HE LIAO Grain Bone 禾髎 He - alcove, hole Liao - grain, rice, corn He Liao is located in the depression of the bone that is the size of a grain, between the teeth and gums Forbidden with moxa Co 20 YING XIANG Welcome Fragrance 迎香 Ying - blessed, to meet, to receive Xiang - smell, the aroma associated with earth This point’s name tells us that CO-20 is the place where the stomach meridian meets the colon meridian. It is the meeting of aromas; this includes the 5 fragrances according to the 5 elements, most significantly the aroma of Earth. Forbidden with moxa. etymology:
Yun - cloud
Men - gate
The lungs are located in the upper jiao, which is full of heavenly water and steam (clouds/mist). Additionally they distribute fluids throughout the body (they are responsible for circulating CHI to the entire body) and function as a cloud that provides rain and nourishment to the earth. The lung - kidney connection is important for body fluid circulation. The lungs spread dampness throughout the body and to the skin and are therefore considered the cloud gate

2.  מחזקת את תפקוד הריאות בהורדת צ'י (צ'י).
3.  נקודת רפלקס לריאות.
4.  נקודת התחלה של זרימת Wei CHI (וויי צ'י) ו- Ying CHI (יינג צ'י).

etymology:
Tian - heavenly
Fu - palace
description: A point with a high concentration of microcosmic energy. The lung's function allows this point to be the place where microcosmic energy connects with the CHI of the entire body, influencing the deepest physical elements of the body
location: On the anterior - lateral aspect of the arm, 3 cun inferior to the axilliary fold, on the radial side of the biceps brachii. or 6 cun on top of LU-5 anterior to the bone How to find it Divide the space between the axilla and the cubital crease into 3 equal spaces, hold the root of the biceps brachii separate it from the bone. The lung points are located in that space
functions:
1. Heavenly star point, regulates yin and yang CHI between the upper and lower body
2. Tonifies KID yin
3. Balances between LU and TH when LU is in excess and TH is weak
4. Balances between Po and Hun
5. Promotes the passing of yin CHI from water to wood
secondary_functions:
Strong influence on the spiritual aspects of the lung
Balances the TH when the TH pulse is weak and the lung pulse is full
Nei Ching
“Needle this point when the patient is constantly thirsty and bleeds from the nose or mouth. Also in instances of joint inflammation, belching, hiccups or pain around the heart”.
“LU-3 should be needled when the patient suddenly becomes thirsty. This condition is seen as a war between the liver and lungs and is accompanied by nosebleed and hemorrhoids.”
Nei Ching -2: “The energy that is gathered at LU-3 and PC-1 comes from the middle jiao. These 2 meridians concentrate the CHI and the middle jiao provides them with blood”.

etymology:
Xia - to protect/guard
Bai - white, the color of the metal element
description: The color white represents the lungs. Showing a quality of protection for the lungs, preserving the meridians metal qualities
location: At the medial aspect of the upper arm 4 cun inferior to the auxiliary fold at the radial side of the biceps tendon (1 cun interior to LU-3)
functions:
1. Balances the yin and yang of LU
2. Balances the flow of CHI in the meridian. This is the point of balance between internal and external flow and the last internal point before the He- sea point where the CHI flows more externally

etymology:
Chi - Chinese measurement (about 1 foot in length)
Ze - swamp, place where river and sea meet
This point is located in the depression 1 foot (cubit) from the hand pulse (LU-9)
location: In the cubital crease on the radial side of the biceps brachii tendon. Easier to feel with arm slightly bent
functions:
1. HE - sea point
2. Water = dispersal point
3. Reflex point
4. From LU-5 - LU-11 LU CHI flows more externally
5. Promotes the dispersal of body fluids (Jin-Ye) to the skin and tendons
6. Expels heat stemming from excess or deficiency in the lungs
7. Stem point of the water along with SI-2
secondary_functions:
Clears heat from the lungs and calms dry cough by dampening the lungs and throat
Dampens the skin and treats itching
Regulates rebellious lung CHI
With ST-40 it clears hot phlegm from the lungs
cautions: Contraindicated when patient has excess phlegm in lungs

etymology:
Kong - hole
Zui - the depth of the hole where excess is gathered and concentrated
Zui relates to the depth of the hole and the ability of the point to store blood and CHI. Xi-cleft points are like internal storage units of CHI for the meridian. They help balance the meridian without affecting the CHI in other meridians.
location: On the palmar aspect of the forearm, 7 cun proximal to LU-9 (5 cun under LU-5) on the line connecting LU-9 and LU-5
functions:
1. XI - cleft point, regulates CHI and blood in the meridian.
2. XI - cleft point, treats all acute situations of the LU
3. Reflex point
4. Regulates rebellious lung CHI
secondary_functions:
Special point for stopping nose bleeds (area controlled by the lung). It does so by regulating rebellious CHI
For acute asthma attacks
Helps the circulation of blood and CHI to the hands.  Useful in treating all states of cold or heat in the hands.

etymology:
Lie - sequence, organization, precise location
Que - partial, not complete, broken, empty, lacking
The CHI of the lung meridian is stored in LU-6. From there like a river bursting through a dam the CHI floods forward and disperses at LU-7
Lie Que, in ancient Chinese refers to lightning. The LU channel slightly diverts from its main path at LU-7 then returns at LU-8. The CHI's path here looks like lightning
functions:
1. The lou point sends a branch to CO-4
2. Master point of the CV
3. Couple point of the Yin Qiao Mai
4. Balances between left and right side of body and balances the circulation of CHI in the body
5. Crucial influence on head and neck
6. Balances between emotional, mental and physical aspects. It's outward motion releases CHI that is stuck at deep layers of the body due to emotional problems and problems expressing emotions
7. Strengthens the Wei CHI at external levels
8. When used with KID-6 on the opposite side, (opening of the CV) it is useful for regulating the flow of CHI and body fluids between the upper and lower heaters and vice versa
Has centrifugal motion. It raises pulses and CHI to the surface
10. Promotes the spreading and lowering of LU CHI
secondary_functions:
Expels phlegm from the lungs
Expels external wind via centrifugal flow and bringing Wei CHI to outer layers
Treats skin problems from external heat and stagnation of internal fluids
Treats chronic cough or asthma by promoting spreading and lowering lung CHI
With KID-6 it helps build yin via the CV
With CO-20 for opening the nose, stuffy nose, runny nose, sneezing and problems with the sense of smell
With CO-4 for clearing wind cold and promoting sweat
cautions: Exercise caution with this point on emotionally sensitive patients

etymology: Jing - river, channel of stream
description: Qu – tunnel, gutter The Su Wen states that the CHI and blood at Jing river points “move without delay”. As a river point the CHI at this point should be flowing abundantly. The name describes the concentration and flow of CHI at this point.
functions:
1. Jing - river
2. Metal = Horary, strengthens metal and concentrates CHI
3. Concentrates CHI
4. Supports lung CHI over a long period of time
5. Strengthens the function of the Po
secondary_functions:
For controlling the sweating mechanism especially excess sweating by strengthening the metal and contracting CHI
For instances of excess expressed in cough, difficulty breathing and asthma caused by lack of CHI in the lungs
Nei Ching
Nei Ching - 38 “In instances of cough and swelling of the face without true edema, needle the Jing river points of lung and stomach (LU-8 + ST41).

etymology:
Yuan - abyss or deep-water source
LU-9 represents a pit from which water is drawn. It is the Yuan point and the point of influence on the blood vessels. Therefore the CHI here is plentiful and deep like a pit.
The word Yuan indicates the connection between LU-9 and the source CHI. It represents the nature of the CHI at this point and reminds us of the point’s location in a small ditch.
description: Tai – big/large
location: At the wrist joint in the depression at the radial side of the radial artery
functions:
1. Shu - stream point
2. Yuan point, receives a branch from CO-6
3. Tu - earth point, mother point
4. Hui point influencing the blood vessels (especially the arteries)
5. Sends CHI to deep layers of the body with a centripetal motion
6. Strengthens the lung’s function of lowering CHI
7. Earth point of Tai Yin with SP-3
secondary_functions:
Balances and stabilizes the flow of CHI throughout the body
Strengthens and jumpstarts the CHI resulting in stronger blood flow in the upper jiao
Considered the best point for CHI balancing and support in the body
Calms external and swollen pulses by sending CHI deep into the body (CAUTION: make sure this is not pathogenic CHI)
For internal and chronic deficiency
Concentrates the flow of blood in the arteries and veins while strengthening the walls of the blood vessels
With CO-17 for Zhong CHI xu
Nei Ching
Su Wen - 16 “In autumn the metal element points should be needled LU-9 +LI-4”.
Nei Ching-24 “When there is Heart pain and every movement the patient makes increases the pain but there is no change in the color of the patient's face this is a sign of a LU CHI problem and one should needle LU-7 +LU-9”.
Su Wen - 20: “The heaven point of the middle portion in pulses of the 9 continents”.

etymology: “Chi” - located in a slight depression where CHI is gathered like a pool
description: Tian – celestial CHI – pool Tian” refers to the point’s location at the upper part of the body near the heart (emperor) who oversees the body like heaven oversees earth
location: In the 4the intercostal space 1 cun lateral to the nipple (on women lateral to the breast), 5 cun from the midline
needling: Diagonal outward in the direction of the meridian 0.3-0.5 cun
functions:
Window of Heaven point
Exit of the PC divergent meridian
Meeting with GB and LU
Shokanten of Jue Yin
Sends blood up or down according to what’s needed
Nourishes the lower Jiao especially the KID and the genital region (particularly in women)
Sends CHI to the sides
Releases pressure from the chest, promotes circulation of CHI and blood
secondary_functions:
1. Local point for swelling and pain of the chest from LIV CHI stagnation
2. Treats pain and pressure of the chest and sides of the body
3. Treats fever accompanied by headache without sweating

description: Tian – celestial Quan – spring The CHI flows down from this point in a manner similar to a mountain spring

description: Nei – internal Guan – gate “Nei” is a reference to the internal aspect of the body. It also shows us the location at the internal aspect of the arm between the LU and HT meridians. It influences the connection between the internal and internal as well as the internal with the external. It has the opposite function to TW5 Wei Guan external gate. “Nei Guan” is also a disease characterized by stiffness of the chest.
location: 2 cun proximal to the wrist crease Between the flexor carpi radialis and the palmaris longus tendons

Nei Jing -66: “Evil energy (wind, cold, heat etc) attack the person, if they sit in the meridians, they will block them. This can be seen at the Lou points if they are full on the upper limbs”.

Needle the Yuan points of heart and pc (pc7 +ht7)”

description: Tian – heavenly, celestial Zong – ancient SI11 and HT have a direct connection. This point is located near he Shu point of HT. SI11 is a point where CHI accumulates. Tian Zong is also a name of a constellation. SI11 influences the points in its vicinity like a group of stars

It usually is sensitive under pressure

Xi - valley, notch
description: Located in a narrow depression behind a joint As a Shu – stream point the CHI flow at this point should be smooth and fast, like a stream through a valley
location: Proximal to the head of the 5th metacarpal bone, on the line between the red and white skin, easiest located while the patient makes a soft fist
needling: Perpendicular 0.5 – 1 cun with a relaxed fist, for spasm of the finger needle towards CO4 approximately 1.5 – 2 cun
functions:
1. Shu – stream point
2. Wood – mother point
3. Master point of GV
4. Couple point of Yang Qiao Mai
5. Reflex point
6. Pulls excess CHI from GB
7. Purifies wind heat
secondary_functions:
Strengthens the patient who has difficulty coping, strengthens the wood fire connection
Clears hot and cold wind - helping neck and headache, back pain radiating along the spine. Opens stagnation of CHI via its connection to BL
For rheumatism of the arms
Treats neck and finger pain
For deafness, nose bleed and red eyes
Treats fatty bowel movement
Clears wind from the GV - treating internal wind, spasm, trembling, epilepsy stiff neck and headaches
Treats back pain stemming from spinal problems by way of its connection to GV
Influences the thyroid and the adrenal cortex
Raises cortisol levels via its influence on the kidneys
With BL-62 for acute/chronic pain by opening the GV
12. Treats epilepsy with HT7 + CV-15
Nei Ching
Su Wen:”When Tai Yang CHI is weak SI-3 must be needled in order to strengthen the division”.

etymology:
Wan - wrist
Gu- bone
description: Showing us the point’s location near the base of the 5th metacarpal bone
location: In the notch at the ulnar side of the hand between the pisiform bone and the 5th metacarpal bone where the skin changes color
needling: Perpendicular 0.5-1 cun 1. Yuan - receives a branch from HT-5 2. Reflex point 3. Clears blockages from the meridian
secondary_functions:
Treats weak hands with inability to lift objects
For Jaundice (heat and dampness in the middle jiao)
For pain and inflammation of the wrist, Bi - syndrome
Influences the SI area on the back
Treats spasm
Cleanses hot phlegm in the middle jiao
With SI-1 it cleans and opens the facial orifices
With HT-9 for numbness and lack of sensation in fingers and toes

etymology: There a 3 points on the yang aspect of the hand:  CO-5 Yang XI yang stream, TW-4 Yang Chi yang pool, SI-5 Yang Gu yang valley
description: Yang – yang Gu – valley
location: At the ulnar aspect of the wrist, in the depression between the pisiform and the styloid process of the ulna, on the line between the red and white skin
functions:
1. Jing - River
2. Fire = Horary
3. Dispersed to clear heat and dampness from the lower jiaw  especially the bladder
4. Clears blockages from the meridian
secondary_functions:
1. Direct influence on the opposite knee, especially for Bi – syndrome with heat expressed in hot, red legs
2. Treats impotence and lack of sexual ability from yang xu

etymology: SI-6 nourishes the elderly patient with yin. It influences the eyes, ears, knees, lower back and shoulders,
description: Yang – to balance, treat (not the opposite of yin) Lao – old age It is also a point that influences the patient’s self awareness
location: With the hand resting on the chest, the point is located on in the depression at the center of the styloid process of the ulna find the notch in the bone while moving the hand
functions:
1. Xi-cleft, regulates blood and chi in the meridian
2. Tonifies yin and body fluids
3. Strengthens our inner vision, consciousness and sensitivity to our surroundings
secondary_functions:
1. Treats CHI Xu in the elderly suffering from lower back pain, decreased vision
knee pain, shoulder pain and deafness
2.  Provides strength in states of CHI Xu
3. Strengthens YE the synovial fluid that softens the joints, Strengthens the tendons
and ligaments on the SI meridian
4. Located directly above the wrist which undergoes many changes throughout one's
lifetime, often becoming stiff and painful due to weak yang. This point is used to
treat these problems in the elderly

description: Zhi – branch, supporting pillar Zheng – correct, upright, to put a thing in its proper place, regulate The lou point of SI connecting it to HT. Zheng is a reference to HT who establishes the laws in the kingdom. Also refers to the HT's state of health
location: With the hand resting on the chest, SI7 is located 5 cun proximal to the wrist, on the line connecting SI-5 and the lateral epicondyle of the arm at the radial aspect of the ulna
functions:
1. Lou – sends a branch to HT-7
2. Balances between heart and small intestine, balances fire.
secondary_functions:
3. Calms the SHEN
4. Brings down Yang from head, useful in the treatment of heat waves
5. Influences the YE
6. Good for neck and shoulder problems
7. With CO6 strengthens KID Yin
8. Use with CO7 + SI8
9. With BL58 it is helps build the Tai Yang and strengthens general Yang in body
10. With SP10, LU5, CO15 and SI7 to treat hair loss in men and children
11. Used together with SI3 it dampens and speeds up the circulation of water in the body

description: Xiao – small Hai – sea The sea point of the SI meridian where the CHI flows at a deeper level, Xiao is a reference to the small intestine. It is located opposite from HT3 Shao Hai
location: With the elbow flexed, halfway between the olecranon of the ulna and the medial epicondyle
functions:
1. He – Sea point
2. Earth – Child point
3. Deep energy point of SI (earth)
secondary_functions:
1. Clears hot dampness in acute situations of inflammation and swelling of the throat
2. Calms the SHEN, good for nervousness
3. With SI7 to jump-start and strengthen circulation of fluids in the body, strengthens
KID Yin
4. For difficulty turning the head left/right
5. Brings CHI down from the sides of the face
6. With CO6,7 + SI7,8 helps strengthen KID Yin by way of the TH internal duct.
7. Useful for Inflammation of ears, deafness from inflammation, tooth pain, numbness/lack
of sensation in the arm and hand, pain of the lower abdomen, uncontrolled movement,
trembling of limbs, stiffness, compromised motor ability in the fingers

description: Jian– shoulder Zhen – truth, principal, upright, possibly true Very important point located on the shoulder
location: 1 cun superior to the posterior axillary fold, where the fold meets the muscle, located with the arm pressed against the body
functions:
1. Crucial for diagnosing shoulder problems
2. Balances fire – wood  when the pulses of GB and SI are strong.
secondary_functions:
3. Treats shoulder problems
4. Reflex point for the endocrine system, influences local glands
5. SI9 (left side) + SP6 (right side) to treat shoulder pain in women resulting from trauma
6. With SP6 good for shoulder pain in men (not from trauma)

description: Yin – hidden Bai – white The first point on an earth meridan. The earth element births metal. Metal, at its core begins in earth. White is the color of metal.
location: At the medial aspect of the big toe, 1 fen proximal and lateral to the corner of the nail
functions:
1. Jing – Well point
2. Wood
3. Exit point of SP -TMM
4. Influences the SP divergent
5. Root point of Tai Yin. It is connected to CV12 which is considered the concentration
point of Tai Yin
6. Strengthens the spleens task of holding blood in the vessels
7. Balances quality of blood in terms of Yin/Yang
secondary_functions:
Crucial point for stopping all types of bleeding especially from the womb
For SP CHI XU causing swelling of the abdomen and insomnia
Treats general lack of CHI
Calms the SHEN, 7 moxa seeds cones for sleep problems
Causes motion when an external hot pathogen has invaded
With SP2 to treat disturbance of stomach CHI causing pain near the heart, swollen abdomen, diarrhea and ongoing menstrual bleeding
Nei Ching
Nei Ching – 23: “Used together with ST45 to treat heat accompanied by a heavy sensation in the body and heat in the intestines”.
Su Wen - 36:  “One of the points for using the NEEDLING IN OPPOSITION technique. For disturbances caused by Fong (perverse wind). The patient will be sad, groaning, lack of appetite, suffer from ongoing heat and tremors. When he begins to sweat he will vomit because the evil CHI will have weakened him. In this situation needle SP1+SP4”.

description: Xue – blood Hai – sea This point has a strong influence on the blood level. Its influence is in 2 spheres Promoting blood flow and clearing blood stasis. Chilling and purifying blood The above actions remind us that this point can be used to treat a wide variety of gynecological and dermatological problems.
location: 4 cun superior to the tibio - femoral joint line, (2 cun above the upper border of the patella) directly above SP9, in the depression in the Vastus Medialis muscle
functions:
1. Sea of blood point
2. Supports HT yin by forming blood
3. Receives a branch from the Chong flowing from ST12- ST31- SP10- ST36-SP4
4. Influences the blood on all levels strengthens the formation of blood by way of its
connection to chong
5. Purifies blood
secondary_functions:
1. Chills blood. Useful point in treating skin issues i.e. eczema, allergies, urticaria and
itching. Particularly for chronic states with acute appearance as a result of blood
xu and heat in the blood
2. Clears blood stagnation especially in the womb. Promotes blood flow
3. Regulates menstruation, moves blood in the womb treating dysmenorrhea,
irregular periods, bleeding between periods, and excess menstrual bleeding from heat
or stagnation in the blood.
4. Brings down heat by supporting yin and blood
5. Influences the lower back
6. For hair loss from blood xu or blood not nourishing the head

etymology: Ji – seed - basket
description: Men – door Ji Zou is the position of sitting with one leg spread in this position it is easy to locate SP11 Jing Men Men – door is a reference to an acupuncture point where CHI enters and exits
location: 10 cun superior to the tibio – femoral joint line, at the medial border of the Sartorius muscle between the Abductor Longus muscles, on the line from SP10 – SP12, at the medial aspect of the thigh LOCATION TECHNIQUE Bring both legs together and have the patient flex the leg muscles, a path will be formed when the muscle rises, the medial part of the path is the abductor muscle, slide the finger up, the point is on the muscle
needling: Perpendicular 0.5-1 cun 1. Clears stagnation in the SP meridian 2. Repairs T+T

description: Chong – moving, bursting Men – door Chong is a reference to the bursting quality of the pulse felt near this point. Also this point has a strong influence on the CHI bursting up from the area of the pubic bone. MEN – door is a reference to acupuncture points, places where CHI enters and exits
location: Approximately 3.5-4 cun lateral to the midline (CV2), under the asis, at the height of the superior border of the symphysis pubis, lateral to the femoral artery, the point’s location varies according to the location of the artery.
functions:
1. Tonifies yin throughout the body especially in women
2. Meeting with LIV
3. Meeting with the SP divergent meridian
4. Strengthens Yuan CHI
5. Influences the Chong (blood). The pulse at this point is an indication of the
state of the CHONGS function
secondary_functions:
1. Unbinds stagnation in the meridian
2. Treats pain the thigh joint radiating to the pubis from local stagnation
3. Treats stagnation by strengthen yin and unbinding stagnation of LIV CHI and blood

description: Fu – residence She – house In ancient texts these characters represented the intestines or the abdominal cavity as a whole. SP13 is located in the area of the large and small intestines
location: 4 cun lateral to the midline (CV3) 0.7 cun above SP12
functions:
1. On the Yin Wei Mai
2. Meeting with LIV
3. From here the meridian continues to SP14 by way of CV3 and CV4

etymology: Jie - crooked, bent
description: Fu – abdomen, intestines A reference to the bend in the intestinal pathway , which occur under the point
location: 4 cun lateral to the midline (slightly above CV6) 1.3 cun under SP15
functions:
1. On the Yie Wei Mai
2. Brings CHI to the intestines
3. Influences the intestines
secondary_functions:
1. Treats pain around the naval
2. Treats pain of the naval and peritoneum from hernia and SP CHI XU
3. Treats intestinal issues and food stagnation in the intestines
4. Treats weak digestion accompanied by Stomach pain

description: Da – big, a long horizontal line Heng – horizontal A reference to the wide/horizontal part of the Colon found under this point Part of a group of points that for a horizontal line across the Abdomen CV8, KID16, ST25, SP15,
location: 4 cun lateral to the naval (CV8) 1. On the Yin Wei Mai 2. A branch leaves this point flowing to CV10 -SP15- SP16 3. Tonifies the SP 4. Regulates CHI in the lower and middle Jiao 5. Strengthens CHI throughout the body by way of its connection to CV10
secondary_functions:
1. Strengthens weak and cold limbs, strengthens the Spleens function of controlling the limbs.
This point is used to regulate CHI flow to the entire body
2. Tonifies SP and the earth element, disperses phlegm
3. Treats diarrhea or constipation without stomach ache., tonifies the center

description: Fu – abdomen Al – sorrow A good point for treating intestinal issues which often result in noises similar  to crying or groaning
location: 4 cun lateral to the midline at the height of CV11, 3 cun superior to SP15, in the notch in the middle of the 10th rib
needling: Perpendicular, 0.5-1 cun, find the cartilage of the rib, slightly go down, needle under the cartilage
functions:
1. Point on the Yin Wei Mai
2. Balances wood and earth by way of the branch flowing from GB24- LIV14- SP17 -SP16
3. At this point the Yin Wei Mai leaves the SP meridian and goes to LIV14
4. Connects LIV - SP, tonifies SP and forms balance between earth and wood thereby
strengthening the circulation of CHI and blood
5. This is a point with a strong connection to the wood element. It brings earth CHI to wood
6. Passes wood CHI to SP17, supports CHI in the chest
secondary_functions: Treats imbalance and acidity in the Stomach from wood conquering earth

description: Shi – food Dou – drain A reference to SP's function of overseeing digestion and nourishment. Dou refers to the place that Gu CHI passes through by way of the diaphragm into the lungs
location: 6 cun lateral to the midline, in the 5th intercostal space
functions:
Passes Gu CHI from SP to the chest
One of 5 stations passing Gu CHI to the chest
Receives wood CHI from LIV/GB to help raise CHI to the chest
secondary_functions:
1. Treats respiratory issues from LU CHI xu
2. Clears phlegm from the chest
3. Strengthens Zhong Chi
4. Supports HT
5. Useful in treating chest/rib pain

description: Tian – heavenly divine Xi – valley Heavenly valley, the area (depression) above the diaphragm is considered heaven this is formed by the ribs and the muscles in between them, or the depression where the point is located
location: 6 cun lateral to the midline, in the 4th intercostal space (level with the nipple)
functions:
Passes CHI from processed food from SP to the chest
The CHI rising from SP17 becomes increasingly more pure as it rises. At this point it undergoes more purification
secondary_functions:
1. Treats cough, chest and rib pain
2. Tonifies Zhong and Zheng CHI
3. Treats swollen breasts, Mastitis, used locally for lack of milk and difficulty nursing

description: Xiong – chest Xiang – village Xiang – is also translated as “between steps” a reference to the point’s location in between ribs
location: 6 cun lateral to the midline in the 3rd intercostal space
functions:
1. At this points the CHI rising from SP17 takes on its most pure form and settles in the chest
2. Strengthens Zheng CHI and Zhong CHI
secondary_functions: 1. Treats cough and pain in the chest and ribs

description: The name is a reference to the point’s location at the fleshy part of the toe. It is like a spring found in the earth that is rich in water.
location: At the medial aspect of the big toe, distal and inferior to the first metatarsal phylangee joint and distal to the base of the toe between the red and white skin
functions:
1. Ying - spring point
2. Fire -  mother point
3.Tonifies SP and T + T
4. Builds blood by strengthening the digestive system
5. Deep energy point of SP (fire)
secondary_functions:
Used with SP3 for Spleen issues
Awakens mental capabilities
With SP1 for pain near the Heart as a result of disrupted SP CHI flow
Promotes sweating and brings down heat/fever from attack of external hot wind
For developmental problems in children
Treats SP CHI Xu with stomach ache from the spleen’s inability to form blood from Gu CHI and from food stagnation
Direct moxa to strengthen the immune system
Dispersed to bring down fire and cleanse heat
Nei Ching
Nei Ching – 24.2: “Pain at the area of the heart caused by rising of YIN CHI from the zang organs accompanied by abdominal swelling, mucus in the chest, heaviness and acute pain in the heart area, the treatment is SP2+SP3”.

description: Zhou – everything Rong–  to blossom, honor, shine The Spleen is responsible for transformation and transportation of essences that nourish the body. The LU receives these essences from the Spleen and spreads them throughout the body in the form of CHI or fluids. SP20 is located under LU1. These 2 systems have a mutual influence on nourishing the body.
location: 6 cun from the midline in the 2nd intercostal space
functions:
1. Meeting point of pre and post natal CHI
2. Meeting of heavenly CHI and earthly CHI (SP20-LU1). Useful in passing Gu CHI to the lungs to form Zhong CHI. Influences the connection between Gu CHI and Kong CHI
3. Strengthens the Tai Yin division
4. Increases the circulation of general CHI from the chest to the rest of the body
secondary_functions: 1. Treats cough and pain of the chest and ribs

description: Da – big, important Bao – wrapping A reference to the LOU meridians that flow from this point to the chest and wrap the entire body
location: On the mid - axillary line In the 7th intercostal space
functions:
1. The Spleen's big Lou point. Attaches all the Lou meridians in the body
2. Controls all the capillaries, lou meridians and small blood vessels, disperses fluids through out the body, treats weakness of the entire body
3. Sends out branches which provide the body with stomach CHI
4. Branches of the Lou meridian wrap the chest and nourish the entire body
secondary_functions:
1. Regulates CHI throughout the body
2. Helps build Jin and Ye from the ST that nourishes the entire body
3. Useful for treating pain of the entire body resulting from excess stuck in the center
4. Dispersed when the point is empty and there is general weakness of the body
Nei Ching
Nei Ching-10: “The branches of the big Lou meridian serve and nourish the body's fluid channels which flow from the stomach to all the organs”.
“If the big Lou meridian is full there will be pain throughout the body, disperse the stagnated CHI by dispersing this point”.
“If the Lou meridian is empty, the joints will be too loose, tonify this point”.
cautions: 1. Avoid deep needling 2. Avoid needling if uncertain of its necessity 3. Needling this point may disperse the earth CHI causing the patient to be empty of earth CHI Xin Heart 心 The monarch Heavenly unification the heart controls all organs and represents the awareness of human existence, it is responsible for the wisdom, for the spiritual change and the brightness of the spirit stems from it 5 elements phase: Fire Celestial stem: Ding 丁 Terrestrial Branch: Wu 午 Trigram: Dui 兌 lake, a joy, the middle of autumn that delighted the multitude of things Six Division: Shao Yin Climate: Fire Deep Energy: Fire Direction: South Season: Summer Chinese Clock: 11:00-13:00 Animal: Horse

description: Tai – upper Bai – white Tai Bai is the Chinese name for Venus. The earth point on an earth meridian it can strengthen earth CHI at its foundation and help the formation of metal Also a reference to the Tai Bai Mountains in China. The point is located after the “mountain” that protrudes from the foot. The skin here is white.
location: At the medial aspect of the big toe, proximal and inferior to the head of the first metatarsal bone where the skin color changes
needling: Perpendicular 0.2-0.5 cun FUNCTION 1. Shu - Stream point 2. Yuan - receives branch from ST40 3. Earth – Horary point, Tonifies metal 4. Crucial point for strengthening SP 5. Strengthens mental functioning, improves memory and promotes mental clarity 6. Stem point of earth (with GB34) SECONDARY FUNCTION Moves and disperses phlegm by strengthening earth Excellent for strengthening the spine especially for chronic back pain Treats atrophy of abdominal muscles after giving birth Treats the after effects of trauma Used to disperse dampness in all 3 heaters i.e. sensation of heaviness in the head with a foggy mind, productive cough, fullness of the chest, swelling of the epigastrium, lack of appetite. In the lower jiao: urinary problems, dark urine, vaginal excretions, difficulty urinating, and when the tongue coating is thick Strengthens the bones by building blood Nei Ching Nei Ching - 28: “Needle in states of leg paralysis” 28.3: “In a state of weakness and cold in the limbs with a sensation of fullness and attack in the chest and heart needle SP3 and LIV3” 23.3: “In states of heaviness of the body and hot disease that cause heat in the intestines needle SP3 and ST43”
cautions: Excess needling can cause spleen weakness and formation of excess phlegm in the body

etymology: Gong Sun was the family name of the Yellow Emperor who ruled from 2597-2607 BC, The period of time in which he lived in is connected to the earth element thus “yellow” emperor. SP4 is the Lou point of the earth Element connecting 2 organs that have earth energy. This is of great importance to the body just as the period of time in which the yellow emperor served is important to all of history.
description: Gong – grandfather, community, family name Sun – grandson
location: In the depression distal and inferior to the base of the first metatarsal bone where the red and white skin meet. Find SP3 and the 1st metatarsal protuberance, from the base of the 1st metatarsal bone slide slightly proximal until the raised area is felt
functions:
1. Lou point send branch to ST42
2. Master point of Chong Mai
3. Couple point of Yin Wei Mai
4. Regulates CHI of SP/ST
5. Activates the Chong Mai
6. Tonifies the stomach in situations of CHI deficiency in the stomach forming
fullness and heaviness in the middle jiao
7. By way of the Chong Mai it connects prenatal and postnatal CHI
8. Builds blood - some sources claim it is one of the seas of blood by way of its
connection to Chong Mai
secondary_functions:
Disperses fullness particularly that resulting from phlegm and heat in the stomach, treats accumulation of phlegm in the epigastrium and heat in the Stomach.
Benefits menstruation, regulates the monthly period
Treats Stomach problems accompanied by frequent vomiting and stomach pain

description: Shang – the 5th musical note Qiu – hill, mound, mine The tone “shang” is related to the metal element. It is the 5th tone. Qiu is a reference to the medial malleolus. The name is a reference to the metal point on an earth meridian (like a quarry next to a mountain)
location: At the meeting of the anterior and inferior borders of the medial malleolus, in the depression
functions:
1. Jing - River point
2. Metal, Child point
3. Meeting point of the veins. The metal CHI strengthens spleens task of holding blood
in the vessels
4. Strengthening point for the spleen and stomach. The metal concentrates the functions
of Spleen and influences the functions of stomach
secondary_functions:
Transforms dampness by repairing the Spleen's function
Treats stomach pain, intestinal noise, diarrhea, hemorrhoids and lack of appetite
As a metal point, it has concentrated and contracting qualities, good for problems of the veins like swelling, pain and varicose veins
Treats problems along the Spleen meridian i.e. rheumatism, pain and contraction of muscles, swelling, rashing, etc.
Dispersed for local pain from excess and stagnation in the SP meridian

description: San – 3, Yin – yin Jiao – crossing The meeting place of the 3 leg yin meridians
location: 3 cun above the medial malleolus, in the depression posterior to the medial border of the Tibia
functions:
1. Meeting of the 3 leg yin meridians
2. Reflex
3. Crucial point for lower abdomen, fertility and menstruation
4. Used with moxa it sends CHI upwards
5. Supports KID CHI and KID yin
6. Strengthens SP and disperses phlegm
7. Opens up stagnation in the LIV
secondary_functions:
1. Strengthens spleen and kidney, promotes formation of CHI and blood, nourishes
blood and yin
2. Builds the bones, helps heal broken bones
3. Expels hot/cold dampness especially from the lower jiao. i.e. yellow or white
vaginal excretion, phlegm in the feces, dark, cloudy urine, itching of the testicles or
vagina, inflammation of the urinary bladder
4. Strengthens and supports liver function, preserves the smooth flow of LIV CHI
treats stagnation of the lower jiao causing stomach ache, menstrual pain and constipation
5. Moves blood and prevents stagnation particularly in the womb
6. Chills blood, treats chronic and acute skin disease
7. Stops pain particularly in the lower jiao by moving LIV CHI
8. Treats insomnia, useful in treating disharmony of SP – HT from lack of blood and yin
9. Used in treating all gynecological disorders. Regulates the womb and menstruation,
menstrual pain, irregular periods, inflammation of the vagina, bleeding, excretions,
fertility problems, impotence and nighttime seminal emission
10. With CO11 to treat wounds on the skin from heat in the blood
11. With SP8 to influence the womb
12. With ST36 to tonify ST/SP, postnatal CHI, blood and the entire body,
treats chronic weakness and fatigue
With KID23 + KID3 + KID6 + SP6 to tonify KID yin
Nei Ching
Ling Shu 9.2:“Diarrhea with undigested food from SP CHI XU should be treated by tonifying SP6+SP9”
Ling Shu 23.3 - “Hot diseases with excessive sweating should be treated with SP6”

etymology: Gu - valley
description: Lou – leak The name describes the topographic location of the point, in a depression formed by the tibia bone and the gastrocnemius muscle Gu is cereral. When the Spleen is not managing the Gu CHI and there is leakage of CHI the result will be fatigue and thinning Accumulation of phlegm, a valley which leaks out phlegm
location: 6 cun above the medial malleolus, posterior to the medial border of the Tibia, on the line connecting SP6 – SP9
functions:
1. Regulates fluids and solids in the body and promotes their release
2. Promotes urination and bowel movement

description: Di – earth Ji – to heal, crucial point
location: 10 cun above the medial malleolus, posterior to the border of the tibia, on the line connecting SP6-SP9
functions:
1. XI - cleft regulates CHI and blood in the meridian
2. Crucial influence on the womb
secondary_functions:
Opens blockages in the meridian
Influences the womb, lower abdomen and intestines
Regulates the womb
Treats dysmenorrhea
Regulates menstrual blood
Used with other points on the meridian to support their function(s)
Nei Ching
Su Wen 46: “Needle for lumbar pain with a hot sensation of the upper body, when the patient can not turn his head. For the same symptoms with a cold (with no hot sensation) sensation needle ST36”

etymology: Lin - hill, tomb, mound
description: Yin – yin Quang – spring A topographic description of the point, located near the knee at the medial part of the body it is also a water point. This shows us the strong Yin quality of the point
location: In the depression posterior and inferior to the medial condyle of the tibia.
needling: Perpendicular, along the posterior border of the tibia, 0.5-1 cun
functions:
1 He – sea point
2. Water point
3. Reflex
4. Tonifies Spleen yin
5. Exit point of the SP divergent
6. Clears hot phlegm from lower jiao
secondary_functions:
1. Clears Edema, swelling and water retention particularly from the legs, knees and abdomen
2. Treats all urinary problems, promotes urination
3. Tonifies the lower jiao
4. Unbinds blockages in the meridian
5. Supports the formation of blood
6. Calms GB heat invading earth especially SP
7. Treats menstrual imbalances
8. For women’s issues from excess blood and CHI or stagnation in the SP meridian
Nei Ching
Nei Ching – 1: “Needle in all cases of accumulation at the upper and internal portions from the body's yin being attacked”
Nei Ching – 23: “Needle with KID1 when there is a hot pathogen present. The patient will suffer from severe pain near the naval.”
Su Wen – 47: “When there is a bitter taste in the mouth use SP9. This is a result of heat in
the GB”

description: Cheng– to contain, hold Qi – tears Located directly under the Orbit in the depression that catches the tears
location: Directly under the center of the pupil at the inferior border of the Orbit. Between the eyeball and the superior aspect of the inferior Canthus
needling: Perpendicular 0.5 cun with the patient looking up, hold and gently press the eyeball, slowly insert the needle along the inferior border of the orbit
functions:
1. Point on the Yang Qiao
2. Treats eye problems
3. Meeting with CV
4. Meeting with the SP divergent meridian
5. Sends CHI down
secondary_functions:
1. Expels wind from the eyes, brightens the eyes
2. Treats spasm of the eyelids, eye pain, tearing, excretions and inflammation of the eyes
3. Useful in treating paralysis of half the face
4. With BL1 for eye problems
cautions: Contraindicated from the 1st month of pregnancy
description_hebrew:
נקודה: St1
שדה: תיאור

צֶ'נג – להכיל, להחזיק צ'י – דמעות. ממוקמת ישירות מתחת לארובה (אורביט), בשקע שתופס את הדמעות.
location_hebrew:
נקודה: ST1 (דְּוֵי מוּ)

שדה: מיקום

טקסט לתרגום:
ישירות מתחת למרכז האישון בגבול התחתון של ארובת העין. בין גלגל העין והחלק העליון של הקַנְתוּס התחתון.
needling_hebrew:
נקודה: St1 (וויי צ'נג/ווייצ'נג - 魏承)
תחום: דיקור

טקסט לתרגום:
ניצב 0.5 צון, כאשר המטופל מסתכל למעלה, להחזיק וללחוץ בעדינות על גלגל העין, להחדיר את המחט באיטיות לאורך הגבול התחתון של ארובת העין.
functions_hebrew:
נקודה: ST1 (דוּ וֵיי - Dū Wèi)
תחום: פעולות

1. נקודה על היאנג צ'יאו (Yang Qiao)
2. מטפלת בבעיות עיניים
3. נקודת מפגש עם ה-CV (רֵן מַאי - Rèn Mài)
4. נקודת מפגש עם המרידיאן המתפצל של הטחול (SP)
5. מורידה צ'י (Qi) כלפי מטה
secondary_functions_hebrew:
נקודה: ST1 (צ'נג צ'י, Cheng Qi)
תחום: פונקציות משניות

1. מסלקת רוח מהעיניים, מבהירה את הראייה
2. מטפלת בספאזם של העפעפיים, כאבי עיניים, דמעת, הפרשות ודלקות בעיניים
3. יעילה לטיפול בשיתוק של חצי הפנים
4. בשילוב עם BL1 לבעיות עיניים
cautions_hebrew:
נקודת דיקור: סט1 (St1)
תחום: אזהרות

טקסט לתרגום:
התוויית נגד מהחודש הראשון להריון

נקודה: סט 1 (St1, סְטִי 1)
תחום: זהירות

התוויית נגד מהחודש הראשון להריון

description: Shui– water Tu – flow, bulge The pulse of the carotid artery at this point is similar to water flowing gently
location: At the anterior border of the SCM halfway between ST9 and ST11
functions:
1. Promotes the flow of CHI in the upper portion of the body
2. Raises CHI to the head
3. Flows CHI down from the head
secondary_functions: 1. Treats all CHI blockages in the throat and neck area

etymology: ST13 - door
description: Qi – qi She – dwelling The names of the ST points on the chest are metaphors for their locations in the “house” of the chest ST11 – house ST14 – storage place ST15 – roof ST16 – window The breath passes the area of ST11, located next to the Trachea
location: Superior to the sternal border of the Claviculae bone, in the depression halfway between the 2 heads of the SCM muscle. (Between the 2 heads of the SCM in the depression between the manibrium and the claviculae, at the medial aspect)
needling: Perpendicular 0.3-0.5 cun, superior to the depression in the bone
functions:
1. Point with strong concentration of CHI before it rises to the head by way
of the ST meridian
2. Point with strong concentration of CHI before it descends to the middle and lower
body by way of ST12 and the rest of the ST meridian
needling_hebrew:
נקודה: קיבה 11 (Wei 11, ווֵי 11)
שדה: דיקור

טקסט לתרגום:
ניצב 0.3-0.5 צון, מעל לשקע בעצם.

תרגום:
ניצבת 0.3-0.5 צון, מעל לשקע בעצם.
functions_hebrew:
נקודה עם ריכוז חזק של צ'י (צ'י – תעתיק: צִ'י) לפני שהוא עולה לראש דרך
מסלול המרידיאן של הקיבה (ST).
נקודה עם ריכוז חזק של צ'י (צ'י – תעתיק: צִ'י) לפני שהוא יורד למרכז ולפלג הגוף התחתון
דרך נקודה קיבה 12 (ST12) ושאר מסלול המרידיאן של הקיבה (ST).

etymology: The supra- clavicular fossa is also similar in form to an empty bowl
description: Que – empty Pen – bowl, hips “Pen gu” (basin bone) was the ancient Chinese nickname for the Clavicule.
location: Superior to the claviculae, in the center of the Supra clavicular depression, 4 cun lateral to the CV
needling: Perpendicular 0.3-0.5 cun, do not damage local blood vessels or lungs
functions:
1. Meeting of the 3leg yang TMM
2. Meeting with Yin Qian Mai
3. Meeting with SI, TW, GB, CO
4. Influences the Chong MO by way of stomach's internal meridian flowing to
ST30- SP10- ST36
5. Brings CHI down from the upper body to the legs
secondary_functions:
1. Promotes circulation of CHI and blood throughout the body
2. Brings CHI down

description: Qi – qi Hu – gate Located on top of the lung, heavenly CHI must pass this point on its way to the lung. It is likened to a door that CHI passes through. This is also the point where ST and the 3 yang meridians of the arm leave their internal meridians to connect to the main meridians and flow to the head and vice versa. This is another example of CHI entering and exiting.
location: Inferior to the clavicule, under ST12, 4 cun from the CV. There are 8 cun from the tip of the Claviculae to the CV divide this distance in half.
functions:
1. At this point ST, CO, SI, TW leave their main meridians to attach to the divergents
2. The divergent meridians of ST, CO, SI, TW come to the surface and attach to the
main meridians
3. Builds over all yin and KID yin
4. Strengthens the internal duct of TH
secondary_functions:
1. Treats fullness and pain in the chest and ribs
2. Treats cough and shortness of breath
3. Nourishes the chest with CHI

description: Ku – storage Fang – deficiency Its location on the chest is seen metaphorically as a storage room for the Heart and Lungs
location: In the first intercostal space, directly above the 2nd rib, 4 cun lateral to CV20
functions:
1. Disperses stagnated blood and CHI in the chest
2. Sends CHI downwards
3. Calms the SHEN
4. Promotes the lungs downward dispersal of CHI
5. Regulates rebellious Stomach CHI
secondary_functions: 1. Treats stagnation of CHI and blood in the chest

description: Swu – room, house Yi – roof The Lungs are the Zang organ with the highest location they are seen as a canopy. This point has an important relationship with the lungs and chest. The breast blossom from this point similar to the slant of a roof.
location: In the 2nd intercostal space, directly above th 3rd rib, 4cun lateral to CV19
functions:
1. Disperses CHI and blood in chest
2. Calms the SHEN
3. Sends CHI down
4. Promotes the lowering and dispersal of LU CHI
5.Regulates rebellious ST CHI
secondary_functions: 1. Eases local tension

description: Ying – breast, chest Chuang – window CHI and milk enter the breast via this point similar light and air entering through a window
location: In the 3rd intercostal space, directly above the 4th rib, 4 cun lateral to CV18
functions:
1.Promotes flow of CHI and blood in chest especially in women
2.Promotes formation of breast milk
3. Expels local heat
4. Clears local stagnation
secondary_functions:
1 .Strengthens formation and flow of breast milk
2. Clears heat and swelling in Mastitis
3. Treats pressure in the chest, stiff chest and cough resulting from emotional stress
4. Treats heat in the chest, heat waves, hot hands, and nervousness appearing as
menopausal symptoms

description: Ru – breast Zhong – center
location: At the center of the nipple
functions:
1. Strengthens the circulation of CHI and blood in breasts
2. Promotes the formation of milk during nursing
secondary_functions:
Treats cysts of the chest
Massage for clearing stagnation expressed in cysts and swelling before menstruation
Contracts the womb

description: Ru – breast Gen – root, source Located at the root of the breast
location: In the 5th intercostal space, on top of the 6th rib, 4 cun lateral to CV16 1. Lou point between ST and Chong 2. Promotes formation of breast milk by bringing middle jiao CHI to the breast 3. Sends CHI upwards 4. Activates the GB promotes the excretion of bile
secondary_functions:
1. Treats burning of the nipple
2. Clears blockages

description: Bu – negative Rong – to contain Of the ST points located on the trunk of the body this is the first one that is not located on the chest/rib cage. When the stomach is full to this point it cannot contain any more food
location: 2 cun lateral to CV14, 6 cun superior to the naval
functions:
1. Calms the stomach by clearing it of food
2 .Regulates the stomach by helping it pass food to the duodenum
secondary_functions:
Treats nausea and vomit
Calms reflux and gas with pressure of the chest
Calms pressure rising from the Stomach to the chest

description: Si – 4 Bai – white Representing the 4 white areas surrounding the Iris above, below and to the sides This point can whiten the 4 sides of the sclara when they are red
location: In the notch in the infra orbital foramen directly under the center of the pupil at the lower portion of the Sphynoid
needling: Perpendicular 0.3-0.8 cun For Trigeminal Neuralgia 0.3-0.6 cun into the Infra Orbital Foramen from above outwards
functions:
1. Brightens the eyes
2. Expels wind from the eyes
secondary_functions:
1. For the local treatment of sinusitis and pain of the maxillary sinuses
2. Treats facialis and pain of the trigeminal nerve
cautions: Contraindicated in pregnancy from the 6th month

SI BAI
